docs.lead_paragraph: Lilia Cuji did not dare ask for welfare last summer when she ventured inside the Jamaica, Queens, outpost of the city's Human Resources Administration, a six-story brick building wedged between Caribbean delis and a topless bar called Dreams. Ms. Cuji, who immigrated from Ecuador six years ago, applied only for Medicaid health insurance benefits for her 2-year-old son, and she provided all the documents necessary to prove his eligibility. But in a little-noticed pilot project that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to expand to the rest of the city next year, the Jamaica center required something more of anyone seeking Medicaid: a home investigation by the same city unit that screens welfare applicants for fraud.

headline.main: New Hurdle for Some Seeking Medicaid: Home Inspections

docs.abstract: New York City tightens Medicaid procedures instituting home investigations of applicants; Lilia Cuji, Ecuadoran who applied at Jamaica office for her son, says she was turned down after home investigator sharply questioned her lack of green card and spotted men's jeans in closet; official explains that further investigation may have found applicant misrepresented her situation and was living with spouse; welfare advocates admit procedures do permit city to uncover fraud; Cuji, whose husband also has no green card, later got Medicaid for child, and for herself because of pregnancy; some analysts say hard-line approach used to deter welfare fraud backfires on health care, because preventive treatment is cheaper than emergency-room care (M)
